title: `AzureAD\` Prefix is ignored and you have to manually type it every time you want to login via RDP
author: BrainSlugs83
body_snippet:
It appears as though the `AzureAD\` user principal name prefix is not honored as specified.  This causes login to fail on many versions of windows (See Recording below) when that machine is joined to an Azure AD domain (as opposed to an on-prem or hybrid AD domain).

Here is a recording of this behavior, where you can see that I have specified `AzureAD\` as a prefix to my user name (in the bottom left), and that the login fails and I have to manually type it to login (you can click on the imag...

comments.snippet:
***AzureAD\user@domain.com*** is **not** a username.
Username is **AzureAD\user**
Domain is **domain.com**
Put those information in the appropriate fields and things should work:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22905106/93265020-486eaa80-f7a8-11ea-8ec4-bc23d0e55961.png)


I don't have any way to test this out but I cannot think of any reason why this shouldn't - If not feel free to reopen this for further investigation.

comments.snippet:
For myself (in a year's time) and anyone else who might benefit:

```
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\WinStations\RDP-Tcp
Change "SecurityLayer" to 0
```

Disable CredSSP (Set to No) in connection profile
Username: `.\AzureAD\<upn>` (yes the dot slash is required to avoid the AzureAD prefix from being removed)
Password: `<Office 365 password>`
Domain: `<blank>`

I did get RDP to work, but NLA must be off on the AzureAD machine OR AzureAD VM and had to add these 2 lines to the end of the RDP file:

enablecredsspsupport:i:0
authentication level:i:2

(Worked like a champ, RDP does pass ".\AzureAD\")

comments.snippet:
For my future self:

Username: domain\username
Password: O365 Password
Domain: Blank
Use CredSSP: No

On the laptop side, under System properties>remote:
Check "Allow Remote Assistance connections to this computer"
Only select "Allow remote connection to this computer", no need to hit the check box underneath for NLA. 


This allows me to connect with any other modifications.
comments.author: Nasyncs

comments.snippet:
Just throwing in my "fix"

Username: .\AzureAD\myname@mydomain.com
Password: My O365 password
Domain: Blank

Use CredSSP: No
Server Authentication: "Warn me if authentication fails"

The server authentication part was what was missing for me.
